APPLIED CATALYSIS A: GENERAL ELSEVIER Applied Catalysis A: General 158 (1997) 273-285 Studies on deactivation kinetics of a heterogeneous catalyst using a concentration-controlled recycle reactor under supercritical conditions Fenghui Niu, Hanns Hofmann* Institute of Technical Chemistry L University of Erlangen-Nuremberg, Egerlandstrasse 3, 91058 Erlangen, Germany Received 20 August 1996; received in revised form 22 November 1996; accepted 22 November 1996 Abstract A concentration-controlled continuously operated recycle reactor was applied to study the deactivation kinetics of the heterogeneous catalytic disproportionation of ethylbenzene (EB) under supercritical conditions. First the possibility of this method was studied by simulation. On the basis of this simulation it was experimentally realised, thanks to the slow deactivation of the catalyst under supercritical conditions and high feed mole fraction, to determine directly the catalyst activity vs. time on stream. The method seems to be superior to classical methods based on the stationary kinetics of the reaction system. A model for the deactivation kinetic is presented. Keywords: Kinetics; Deactivation; Ethylbenzene disproportionation; Supercritical conditions 1. Introduction The deactivation of heterogeneous catalysts, particularly zeolites, is an impor- tant problem in chemical and petro-chemical industry, e.g. cracking, hydrocrack- ing, isomerisation, etc. Catalyst deactivation by coking can be prevented or retarded by in situ dissolution of coke precursor under supercritical reaction conditions [1-3]. The activity or the deactivation kinetics of catalysts is traditionally determined on the basis of stationary kinetics. According to the suggestion of Levenspiel [4] * Corresponding author. Tel.: (+49-9131) 857424; fax: +49 9131 857421; e-mail: H.Hofmann@tc.uni- erlangen.de. 0926-860X/97/$17.00 1997 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved. PII S0926-860X(96)00404- 8 274 F. Niu, H. Hofrnann/Applied Catalysis A: General 158 (1997) 273-285 the method of concentration control in recycle reactors was proposed by L6we and others (see [5-7]). By means of this control the reactant concentrations in the reactor can be kept on a predefined level. Therefore, the concentration-controlled recycle reactor was evinced as a valuable instrument for investigations of reaction kinetics [8-10] as well as for the determination of catalyst activity at ambient pressure [11]. In this study, the activity and deactivation kinetics of a HY-zeolite (HYZ) under supercritical conditions (P>45 bar, T>550) were determined in a continuously operated recycle reactor with concentration control, where ethyl- benzene disproportionation (EBD) into benzene (B) and diethylbenzene (DEB) served as test reaction with pentane as inert. For similar studies with other inerts see [ 12]. The method of concentration control allows elegantly to determine immediately the catalytic activity without extra data for the stationary kinetics. Up to now experiments using concentration control have been reported only for ambient pressure. Owing to the slow deactivation of catalyst under supercritical conditions and high ethylbenzene (EB) concentration, it is possible to realise the concentra- tion control also at high pressure. 2. Experimental equipment The computer-controlled experimental equipment consists of a feeding system, a gradientless recycle reactor, a gas chromatograph (GC) for the analysis of the reaction mixture, and a data processing and control unit consisting of two PCs. One was used for the input of operating conditions and initial concentrations as well as simulation of an ideal continuously operated recycle reactor, the other for storing the analysis results, estimation of kinetic parameters and the catalyst activity and saving the simulation results on hard disk. A detailed description of the experi- mental set-up can be found in [13]. 3. Simulation of the activity determination 3. l. Method and principle of concentration control The conception of the concentration control is based on the following assump- tions [5]" the reaction scheme and the reaction stoichiometry is known, the system is in quasi-stationary state, i.e. the stationary mass balance for a CSTR can be used and each stationary state can be characterised by the mole fraction of reactants and the flow of inert. Additionally for heterogeneous catalytic reactions it must be proved that the intrinsic reaction rate is measured, i.e. neither film nor pore diffusion limitations exist at experimental conditions (see [12]). Simulation for the determination of catalyst activi~ In order to test the capability of the control principle introduced above, simulation programs were developed, which run on the two PCs [12]. In these programs a parameter (called ananum) indicates the number of analysis used for the estimation of the system state Cav. Activity determination by concentration control In order to realise the concentration control, the experimental set-up must provide an automatic analysis and data processing, the storage of analytical results on the computer, the estimation of kinetic parameters with an auxiliary model and adjusting the control variable (feed concentration). The experimental set-up described circumstantially in [13] fully satisfied those prerequisites. 4.1. Experimental design While on the basis of a stationary kinetics, a deactivation model was established for supercritical conditions and small feed mole fraction of EB in the temperature range of 573-673 K [15], a suitable model for large feed mole fractions of EB (YEB,0=0.8) is not available due to the existence of an optimum temperature for the rate of reaction [15]. The selected temperatures ought to be above the optimum temperature and at the same time should not be too high due to strong coking. Therefore, three temperatures (613, 633 and 653 K) were selected. The other experimental conditions were 450Nml/min (total flow rate), 50bar and YEB,0=0.8. 4.2. Experimental results The determination of the catalyst activity can only be reliable if the concentra- tion control functions so well that the set value is achieved quick enough and kept accurately during the experimental time. As an example the control quality for EB is described in Fig. 5. It is shown that the set value of the EB concentration was kept within an error of % during the whole experiment. Fig. 6 shows the activity curves of the catalyst measured at three different experimental temperatures. There is an obvious dependency of the effective activity on temperature. 5. This means that the catalyst deactivates much slower under supercritical conditions and at high feed mole fraction of EB, because coke precursor will be better extracted by concentrated supercritical reaction fluid. 6. Conclusion Deactivation kinetics of a heterogeneous catalyst under supercritical conditions was studied by use of a concentration-controlled recycle reactor. The simulation testified the possibility of this method. The number of analytical values used for the estimation of the system state has a strong influence on the control quality. The simulation showed also that the reaction order in the auxiliary kinetic model does not affect the concentration control. Using the optimal number of analytical values and a first reaction order approximate model, the catalyst activity vs. time on stream was experimentally determined in the suitable range of temperature. A simple kinetic model for the deactivation was proposed at supercritical conditions and high mole fraction of ethylbenzene. The high value of the estimated deactivation energy and small deactivation order deduce that the catalyst deac- tivates much slower under supercritical operating conditions than under atmo- spheric pressure. 284 F.
